page.title: 20LANDSCAPE
page.content: Although most of Wyke Beck is covered by culverts part of it runs through an area that is open to the land. Unfortunately part of this beck has become an unofficial tip. Work is being carried out to tidy the beck. There is evidence that plants, birds, and animals are thriving in the area - buttercups, daisies, dandelions, and forget-me-nots. In the area where the land is rougher rose-bay willow herb, nettles and thistles thrive. There is also evidence of some fauna such as water rats and a colony of frogs with the resultant tadpoles in a smaller area of the beck. Birds are also resident along the beck with the more popular sparrows and starlings being mixed with pied wagtails and swallows. The presence of small animals and birds has attracted a kestrel which can be seen hovering over head.
